Title: Rugby , Politics a good match...
Review: This movie which is called "Invictus" and came out in 2009 talks about the mandate of Nelson Mandela who is played by Morgan Freeman and of the rugby world cup of 1995 that took place in South Africa. This film stars Matt Damon who plays the sprinbocks captain , Pienaar, and who is one of the principal actors . It takes place in the post apartheid South Africa and shows how rugby helped this country to reunite . In our opinion the film could have been more focused on the black people side of the story and on Mandela's political story and how he delt with everything. We think it could have been interesting to see what happenend after the final of this world cup to show us if black and white people really got over the apartheid . For us the only black rugby player of the springbocks (Chester) should have been more in the foreground of the film . it would have been interesting to see how he delt with the whole situation and how he felt with all the hate from the fans . Otherwise overall it was a good film which showed the moving side of the story put forward with the good acting of good actors. The songs add something extra which makes the film emotional. Therefore we give "Invictus" a 7/10. The only down side we really have is that there were too many white actors. We would recommend this film as it shows the historical background of South Africa. It allows us to know Mandela's story and who he was, what he did for South Africa and the political aspect of the 1995 World Cup. It also shows a difficult period in the country which was ended by rugby and it's interesting to see how a sport can reunite people. This film can be convenient and be enjoyed by rugby fans who also like historical facts.

Title: Great method-acting piece, but shallow.
Review:
As a South African who saw this film on Friday morning, I can tell you you the entertaining, inspiring and enjoyable "Invictus" exceeded all my expectations.

It really is a true story of epic proportions yet it's told with an intimate feel, and it is at least 98% accurate to the events of the time. Clint gets all the big details and so many of the little details right, but he never goes over the top. He directs with minimum fuss and achieves maximum effect, just letting the powerful story unfold without getting in its way.

I watched the 1995 Rugby World Cup and saw Madiba come out in the Springbok jersey. It was a wondrous sight. And when Joel Stransky slotted that drop kick over in the dying minutes and the Boks won, I wept and cheered along with everyone else. After the match millions of South African - of all races - celebrated. It was an amazing time. It was the birth of the "Rainbow Nation". Nelson Mandela is the greatest and most beloved of all South Africans. The man is a living legend, but so human and real. When he was President he brought hope to all South Africans, white and black. We, in my country, will never stop loving this incredible man. Clint Eastwood and Morgan Freeman did South Africa and our beloved Madiba proud. Francois Pienaar is also an amazing South African, an intelligent, big-hearted rugby played who always led by example, and Matt Damon's performance as him was superb. I was glued to the screen for every second of the film's running time (I didn't even move from my seat until the final credit rolled and the house lights came on), and I was moved to tears on several occasions. The final scene was especially touching.

Freeman's performance was magical and I can see him getting as Oscar nomination. If you think his Mandela is too cool to be true, think again. Mandela really is this cool. A brave and intelligent man whose courage and strength of character should serve as an example to people all over the world. After being unjustly imprisoned for nearly 30 years by a cruel and repressive regime, he emerged to run a country and teach its people the meaning of forgiveness and reconciliation.

I thoroughly recommend the authentically detailed, historically accurate "Invictus" to film lovers, Eastwood fans, Nelson Mandela fans and sports fans everywhere in the world. South Africans would be crazy to miss this excellent film, but it deserves to be a hit all over the globe. Let's hope it is.

Viva Clint Eastwood, viva Morgan Freeman, viva Madiba.

PS. I'm a huge fan of Clint Eastwood as both an actor and a director.

Of the films Eastwood has directed, my favorites, in no particular order, are "Unforgiven", "Million Dollar Baby", "Gran Torino", "The Outlaw Josey Wales", "Letters From Iwo Jima", "The Bridges of Madison County","Bird" and "Invictus". Yes, it's really that good. "Invictus" is another winner from Clint. He just seems to get better with age. What a creative roll he is currently on.

PPS. "Invictus" is one of the best sporting movies I have ever seen. But it's also about more than sport.

Title: Can Invictus represent reality ?
Review:
Invictus is a film directed by Clint Eastwood in 2009 to highlight the problem of apartheid. The film starts with the election of Mandela (Morgan Freeman), he decides to fight against the apartheid and racisim between black and white people. To do that he uses rugby to unify his country. When we saw this film at the end my firned and I had the same reaction : it is a good film because the director highlights the important moments of South Africa's history (Mandela, the rugby cup and apartheid). More over even if you don't like rugby, this film can make you love it, with Damon's performance and also the different scenes of rugby game ( angles of camera...). However rugby takes up too much place, even when Eastwood shows us scenes of Mandela's presidency the story is always centered around rugby's problems of South Africa and discussions. That gives us the feeling that the rugby is the solution of Mandela's problems and apartheid's problems but we know the end of apartheid cannot be solved with rugby. In reality, the end of apartheid took place with a referendum in 1991 and it stil has consequences today.

Title: Good film but ...
Review: "Invictus" is a film directed by Clint Eastwood, released in 2009. Morgan Freeman is Nelson Mandela and Matt Damon is Francois Pienaar who are the main actors. Firstly, it's a film about the beginning of Mandela's presidency and we follow a part of his fight against apartheid. Along side we follow the training of the South African rugby team, Springboks, for the Rugby World Cup of 1995. Secondly that's a good movie thanks to the directoy and the actors. The acting of Freeman, Damon and the other actors are good indeed very good. The filming and the environment is done with a great realisation. Especially the metaphor with the rugby team is very nice because it shows the extreme violence of apartheid with a nice credibility. However the music is not as good as the scenes. we said just before the metaphor with rugby is good but it's a little bit too much, the fierceness is extreme in comparison to the reality of the sport but represents well the reality of apartheid and it gives a bad image about rugby. Finally I recommend the film, if you are into rugby and if you like sport in general. Also you have to know a bit about the history of apartheid to understand the film. So we give it a note of 7/10.

Title: Maybe less rugby would have been better
Review:
Not being a rugby fan doesn't make it easy or really pleasant to watch it, however I still find Invictus rather good. Using the Rugby World Cup to solve the apartheid and consequently to unify white and black people was a good idea, Even if I'm not sure that things happened that way. It wasn't so easy to solve. Freeman as Mandela was quite well-played unlike Francois Pinaar for who Matt Damon doesn't fit in. The music is appropriate but was too discreet.

Title: A magnificent story but a start that was long
Review:
To begin with, South Africa is deeply racially and economically divided. Nelson Mandela turns to rugby to unify the county and makes an ally : the team captain, Mr Pieenar.

On the one hand I found that the film takes too long to start. Maybe Invictus would have been better if some scenes had been shortened ? I'm thinking in particular of this scene were Mr. Pieenar visited Nelson Mandela's cell. I recommend this film becauseit is important to be interrested in this kind of subject and that film sums it up well. Still a very good film directed by Clint Eastwood. Morever, I found that the actors, Morgan Freeman and Matt Damon played their roles very well as usual.

Title: An enjoyable tool to understand Apartheid
Review: "Invictus", is a movie by Clint Eastwood that was released in 2009 starring Morgan Freeman and Matt Damon. This movie takes place right after Mandela's election in South Africa. It tells us the story of Nelson Mandela ( played by Morgan Freeman ) and his impact on racism in South Africa. We will also follow François Pienaar, the leader of the Springboks, South Africa's national rugby team during the rugby world championship in South Africa which took place in 1995. We thought that "Invictus" was a pretty good movie, first of all, Morgan Freeman is really convincing as Nelson Mandela and his acting skills are none the less. Even though it's a movie, the story was not too distorted which makes it quite reliable, it also shows us the reality of Apartheid and the importance of Nelson Mandela for the black population. Despite its good points, the movie is not flawless. One of our main complain is that the beginning is really focused on Mandela's political life while the end is more focused on the rugby championship and the importance of Mandela fade progressively away. Here's a list of what we didn't like : Rugby is showed as the solution against racism like it solved all of the problems and we found that there was a bit too much of it. Back to Rugby, except Matt Damon who played the captain of the Springboks, we didn't see the rest of the team as much as him, they're just the "team". The thing we disliked the most was that we didn't see as much of Nelson Mandela's political life and his diplomatic relationship as we would have liked to. Finally, we found that the end was a bit too romanticized and the musics were forgettable. To sum it up, the actors were great as well as the directing but the flaws we described are enough to not make it perfect. Despite all oh this, "Invictus" is a great movie, it can teach you a lot of thing and it's not straight reality, here's a little reminder, it's a Hollywood movie mode by white people without the real victims of Apartheid.

Title: Politics, Sports and South Africa
Review: Invictus is a good film with a good casting released in 2009. Clint Eastwood punches the world of cinema with this film which is about sport and a tragedy. The casting is incredible with Matt Damon and Morgan Freeman. Morever this actor won the oscar for best actor in 2010 for this film which also won ESPY award for the best sport movie in the same year. In 1994, the election of Nelson Mandela marks the end of Apartheid, but South Africa remains a deeply divided nation. This is why the president mixes sports and politics in order to bring together all the ethnicity group. However, sport is pushing aside the country's problems. Due to the film which does not show the real problems because it is centered on rugby. According to us, Invictus shows the different ethnic groups Mandela doesn't get a revenge against white people on the throw of movie. On the countrary, Mandela shows a lot of sharing despite a very difficult past which unfortunatly is overlooked. We notice a beautiful lack of trust between Mandela and his bodyguards who become his friends. A touching story of friendship. Finally, Freeman's accent is bad. We rate it 7/10, because, Invictus doesn't show the reality but is good. We recommend it because it's a "Must-See".

Title: Too, much rugby...
Review: The film Invictus talks about the Apartheid and how Mandela through his election, managed to change the society of South-Africa? The goal of the film is to show segregation in South-Africa and the impact of Mandela wants to show the power of the nation when everybody is united. Invictus was released in 2009 and produced by Clint Eastwood. The principal actors are Matt Damon and Morgan Freeman. Firstly, the construction of the film is boring and long. Besides, we could think that the topic of the film is mainly rugby whereas the main topic is racism and the Apartheid. Talking about rugby! If we don't know rugby's rulesz, you cant't understand the film and you're lost. Due to the fact that we hate rugby, we disliked the film. In addition, there are no emotions. Everything is exaggerated. Also the highlights of the film are very wishy-washy. However, Morgan Freeman incarnated Mandela perfectly. Matt Damon is aood actor. Chester Williams is amazing in his rôle. Music does by Kyle Eastwood, the son of C. Eastwood, represents well the topic of the film. The poem writen by Ernest Henley is well incorporated in the film in spite of it was too present.

Title: The power of a unifier
Review: "Invictus" is a biopic of Mandela, released in 2009, who speaks about his life, apartheid and the gathering of a nation. Mandela tries to stop the apartheid with rugby. In the story, we follow the arrival of Mandela to power. Thanks to the world cup, he wants to reunify the black and white population. Moreover, we follow the evolution of the Springboks players who grow up as the film progresses. In my opinion, I think Clint Eastwood created a great film which nevertheless lacks of realism. In effect, this film didn't highlight the real relationship between black and white people. I would have liked a more historical story. As far as I'm concerned, I think Morgan Freeman has a great appropriation of Mandela's role. The more the film progresses, the more we feel his emotions. To continue, Matt Damon is also a good and beautiful actor. We are taken into the story, moreover in the rugby's matches which are very well recording. In spite of that, the film talks too much about the president Mandela and not enough about his personality. To finish, I recommmend "Invictus" for the entertainment, for the emotions it procured me. The film goes back over a part of the president Mandela's life and the beautiful nation's victory.

Title: good story but more excpetions
Review: The film "Invictus" was produced by Clint Eathwood in 2009. It talks about the president Nelson Mandela of the Republic of South-Africa in 1994. Furthermore, the film shows the life of the black population at this period as well as racism between black and white men. We can see how Mandela tries to unify his country, notably thanks to the rugby world cup. For us, this film is a good film with a beautiful story and provides many emotions. Particularly when the rugby team visits the prison and the cell where Mandela was imprisoned. It's a very strong moment in the representation because we hear the poem "Invictus" that mandela often read. Moreover it's too centered on rugby and is too far away from the true story because in the real life Mandela was not centered on rugby. Furthermore the main character is normally Nelson Mandela but there is another character, the leader of the rugby team and he is much more important. Then there is no suspense, we know already at the beginning how the film will finish. There is a happy end but even if the team has won, racism is Always present. To conclude, we recommend this film because it's a very beautiful film.

Title: GREAT HISTORICAL MOVIE ‼
Review:
We have rather liked the movie Invictus, This film tells the beginning of Nelson Mandela's presidency and particularly his interest for the rugby team named "Stringboks". We think that the camera's angles and acting are pretty good, the movie is dynamic enough despite the historical aspect often boring in films but we recommend it if you love history. It denounces pretty well the pain of black people in South Africa. However we can't quite agree with different points: Mandela is too centered on rugby games throughat the movie. Well, in our opinion it's not the reality, it's sometime exagereted. As for as we are concerned, we give the mark of 6/10. Thank for reading this post.

Title: Unifying a country through sport?
Review:
Heated fights, sports, politics, race and a divided country, what is not to like? If you like drama! Invictus is a movie about Nelson Mandela's (Morgan Freeman) time in office as newly elected president of the republic of South Africa. Through his growing love for sports lies a secret on how to unify the divided country. The job of hosting the world cup in rugby is an essential event in Nelson Mandela's carriers as president and his work on moving forwards as one nation. Mandela sees an opportunity in the rugby team Springboks. The springboks play badly and doesn't stand a chance in comparison to some of the other teams, but Mandela believes that they are the ones who's going to win the world cup. The springboks are a team that the white population of south Africa always has cheered for, with their leader Francois Pienaar (Matt Damon). Francois plays an important role in the unifying of the country. Nelson Mandela contacts Francois and asks him to believe in his team and train them to win the world cup. Throughout the movie the Springboks visit a group of children playing soccer. They play with them and teach them how to play rugby. This many examples on how during the movie the Springboks goes from inly being cheered on by the white population to being supported by the entire country, all rooting for them to win.

It is, in my opinion, a great movie. As I said earlier it has everything you could ask for, drama, sports and so on. Because the movie has a focus on rugby and not politics only, it is for everyone. Even if you don't like sports! Invictus is a movie with true intentions and great casting. It has stories within its own big story about winning the world cup. For example, the small story of the housekeeper in the house of Francois Pienaar's parents and how she slowly becomes a part of the family instead of just working for the family.

This movie is a great example of why biopic is such a good genre. Through the eyes of the main character, in this case Nelson Mandela, you understand his background, and present story, only now explained in a more entertaining way, with the liberties the movie director gets through this style of movie. I don't think I could've personally watch a documentary about a person and be as emotionally devoted to the movie as I was with this.

8 out of 10 stars.

Title: A solid Movie
Review:
As a South African who saw this film on Friday morning, I can tell you you the entertaining, inspiring and enjoyable "Invictus" exceeded all my expectations.

It really is a true story of epic proportions yet it's told with an intimate feel, and it is at least 98% accurate to the events of the time. Clint gets all the big details and so many of the little details right, but he never goes over the top. He directs with minimum fuss and achieves maximum effect, just letting the powerful story unfold without getting in its way.

I watched the 1995 Rugby World Cup and saw Madiba come out in the Springbok jersey. It was a wondrous sight. And when Joel Stransky slotted that drop kick over in the dying minutes and the Boks won, I wept and cheered along with everyone else. After the match millions of South African - of all races - celebrated. It was an amazing time. It was the birth of the "Rainbow Nation". Nelson Mandela is the greatest and most beloved of all South Africans. The man is a living legend, but so human and real. When he was President he brought hope to all South Africans, white and black. We, in my country, will never stop loving this incredible man. Clint Eastwood and Morgan Freeman did South Africa and our beloved Madiba proud. Francois Pienaar is also an amazing South African, an intelligent, big-hearted rugby played who always led by example, and Matt Damon's performance as him was superb. I was glued to the screen for every second of the film's running time (I didn't even move from my seat until the final credit rolled and the house lights came on), and I was moved to tears on several occasions. The final scene was especially touching.

Freeman's performance was magical and I can see him getting as Oscar nomination. If you think his Mandela is too cool to be true, think again. Mandela really is this cool. A brave and intelligent man whose courage and strength of character should serve as an example to people all over the world. After being unjustly imprisoned for nearly 30 years by a cruel and repressive regime, he emerged to run a country and teach its people the meaning of forgiveness and reconciliation.

I thoroughly recommend the authentically detailed, historically accurate "Invictus" to film lovers, Eastwood fans, Nelson Mandela fans and sports fans everywhere in the world. South Africans would be crazy to miss this excellent film, but it deserves to be a hit all over the globe. Let's hope it is.

Viva Clint Eastwood, viva Morgan Freeman, viva Madiba.

PS. I'm a huge fan of Clint Eastwood as both an actor and a director.

Of the films Eastwood has directed, my favorites, in no particular order, are "Unforgiven", "Million Dollar Baby", "Gran Torino", "The Outlaw Josey Wales", "Letters From Iwo Jima", "The Bridges of Madison County","Bird" and "Invictus". Yes, it's really that good. "Invictus" is another winner from Clint. He just seems to get better with age. What a creative roll he is currently on.

PPS. "Invictus" is one of the best sporting movies I have ever seen. But it's also about more than sport.

Title: Unworthy of it's merits
Review:
Frankly, this movie gets far too much credit. It's a movie about Nelson Mandela though, and Morgan Freeman plays him. So yeah, people are going to say they like it. Myself on the other hand, well, I turned it off halfway through. The story telling is muddled and confused, for the first hour all I could think was, what is this movie even about? What exactly is the plot here, and where is the character development? Is it about Nelson Mandela, one of the greatest peace makers of our time, or the rugby team he worked with?

The first 30 minutes are exposition, where nothing happens to any of the characters on screen. There's no moment of emotional impact on any characters in the cast for the first 40 minutes. The only information we receive for the first half is in the form of expositional dialog, characters saying, "The Spring Bucks are a sign of racial inequality. You can't break bread with them. I don't like you because your people are mean. Yada yada." But we as the audience only ever see the genuine inequality of the sport once, in the opening shot. And it's not the Spring Bucks being shown. We never see any direct discrimination from Caucasians at all, honestly. It's weird.

Aside from the rugby arc, we glimpse more deeply into Nelson Mandela himself. But these moments are short, and never focus on the subject at hand. The scenes don't link together properly, each one reiterating what we have already heard, or referring to something irrelevant. We spend more time on Mandela's body guards than could ever be necessary, when almost no time is spent on his work outside of his rugby centric social outreach.

Don't get me started on the sound track, my god it is appalling. There's this constant attempt to cause conflict where there doesn't need to be any. Body guards getting anxious about assassination, crowds booing Mandela out of arenas. But the music doesn't follow. The song at 1:07 is what forced my hand, I had to end it. It was then and there, that I slayed my own vessel to the abhorrent sounds of Colorblind, by Overtone. The "inspirational song" plays after Mandela gives a brief speech about change. Look this song up, try not to end your life, I dare you. It's not a terrible song, I don't like it, but it's cool if you do. However, to play this after a speech from NeLsON MAnDeLA, OOOOoo boy that really shirks my gherken. Ok that's it, I'm out.

Oh yeah, one thing though. It is cool that this is a movie set in South Africa, for that, I am glad it was made. Solely for that reason though, am I ok with its existence. For that, I give it 3 stars. But that's it, for all the talent that went into this movie, it honestly deserves a 1... To, you know, set that average straight. This movie is bad, do not watch it unless it's all you got, or you live in South Africa.

Title: Great rugby and history movie

It takes Americans to make the best ever movie about the great game of rugby. The grunting, the heaving, the sheer passion. The acting was brilliant particularly in the body language between the black and white bodyguards but the acting was great. The games were well explained. The threat of Jonah Lumo well explained. The final was a nail-biter for my friend who knows nothing of rugby. The final game dragged a bit. There were technical issues in the rugby simulation particularly when the ball failed to go 10 m from one kick off. I think Matt Damon and Morgan Freeman deserve their nominations but the cast acted all the way down the list. The music was not as inspirational as say "Cry Freedom".

Title: Movie vs DVD
Review:
I went to the cinema to see this film last year. I was very impressed.

I thought that Morgan Freeman played a very good Mandela and Matt Damon a very plausible Francois Pinnaer.

The direction was extremely good as would be expected from Clint Eastwood.

I was so impressed by the silver screen version, I wanted the DVD as soon as it came out.

I have just watched it for the first time and there is something missing. I am referring to a Clint Eastwood momentary cameo role.

Am I dreaming or what? Did I or didn't I see a shot of the crowd toward the end of the rugby match and in centre shot there was Clint Eastwood with his arms up cheering with the rest.

I have scanned the DVD footage and it ain't there, so I'm of the mind that it has been cut. It's a shame if it has, I think it should have been left in.

There are no deleted scenes in the extra material included on the disk so I have no way of finding out.

Comments welcomed

Title: Eastwoods Best Film to date
Review:
Enlightening, heartwarming and puts rugby where it belongs on the world stage. I thought this film had merit just on historic value but it was extremely well made and gave an insight to the events of our recent past.. I thought all the actors carried their parts well. Damon even fooled us with his accent. Freeman was superbly cast and played his role flawlessly. To my mind an Oscar winning performance. As a rugby fan I have to say some of the acting "on the field" was a little unrealistic. Not only did it lack the intensity and skill of the players but the "restarts" were completely unrealistic and obviously played by actors and not rugby players. Having said that it was a clear and accurate account of the events that actually took place. Many of the "quotes" and events could be taken straight from Pinaars own autobiography written after the 1995 World Cup.

Title: Morgan Freeman
Review: Alright, SO is it just me, or was Morgan Freeman's performance in this movie, Invictus, far from Oscar Nomination worthy? I was genuinely excited to see this movie before its release, due to the political and revolutionary depth of the plot, mixed with an inspiration story about South Africa's Rugby Team. In addition to that, I have almost always loved Morgan Freeman as an actor in previous movies. However, after watching Invictus for the first time, I was a little bit discouraged by the quality of his acting. I have since watched it several more times, enough to come to the conclusion that Morgan Freeman, in some ways, ruined this movie. I feel this way for several reasons, but perhaps the most significant flaw of his performance was that his accent was not very good at all. I mean, granted it is somewhat of a hard accent to conquer I am sure, Freeman did not make for a believable Nelson Mandela. I could not help but notice that each and every line of his, seemed forced and a bit "off". He is a great actor, but I just do not know if accents are his thing. Morgan Freeman has one of the greatest voices in the world of acting, and is known for having such a pleasant demeanor about him. He should stick to roles that lack international accents. Nelson Mandela is such a significant and beloved hero in South Africa, I believe that someone who is attempting to act as Mandela should deliver a firm dialect, but Morgan Freeman's accent was inadequate for the role.

Title: Great story poor rugby representation
Review:
Invictus was a great story. I read the book "Playing the Enemy" that the movie was based on and the movie wasn't nearly as good. But that's not a surprise. I recommend the book. I coach and play rugby in America and I think the rugby scenes were horrific. Clint should have used real athletes for the rugby scenes, not actors. None of the Samoen team even looked Polynesian. They all looked like wimps. The movie made it seem like dropkicks are a big part of the game. They in fact are very rare. I am glad that rugby is shown in the USA because it is so unknown here. Beyond the rugby footage, the movie was very well done. I am currently reading Mandela's autobiography and it gives great insights to his character and motivations. He is truly a great man and I was glad he was portrayed by such a great actor as Morgan Freeman.

Title: Best green screen work ever!!
Review:
The film was a moving story without falling into the common trap of being over-emotional. However, the most remarkable aspect was the seamless green screen work. Usually, I can spot a "screened" shot in milliseconds...not here. Not until the second viewing. And even then, it wasn't overtly noticeable, more a sense of contrasting shadowing.

Damon's work was subtle and powerful. But, after all these years, that's to be expected.

Freeman was perfection itself. No surprise there. My question is, has he ever given a less than stellar performance??

And Clint Eastwood, where to start? I was pleasantly surprised when I watched his directorial debut and have yet to be disappointed. He makes emotionally investing films and pulls powerful performances from all his actors. I can't wait to see what he does next.

Title: Appropriate timing for a great movie.
Review:
Figured it was time I got around to watching this movie, considering how it is currently the Rugby World Cup (although the events that have just happened are slightly different to those in this movie ha ha.) This movie features some great performances by both Matt Damon and Morgan Freeman, they are definitely the highlight of the movie. I think this movie highlights an essential part of the Apartheid conflict, and the struggle to return to normality after freeing Mandela. I also really enjoyed the music in this movie, I felt it appropriately added to the tone where necessary. I felt that Clint Eastwood's direction wasn't anything to run home about, it helps to develop the story where necessary but mostly goes unnoticed. This movie may not be very accessible for those who don't understand rugby, but if you are willing to ignore that, I would consider this to be a enjoyable, uplifting movie, with some great performances.

Title: Perfect!
Review:
None other than this movie could have portrayed those events in a better way. It is indeed a wonderful movie. But, it is a lot more than a movie for me. It inspired me to learn more about South Africa and specially about Nelson Mandela. Planning to read the book on which this movie is based on.

Though the actual events might not have been so dramatic but still I wish I could be part of that final match. It was filmed in a way that for last 3o minutes, I felt I was part of that crowd of 62 thousand.

This is the first time I am writing a review on IMDb and it is the movie which made me do so. Only one word can describe this movie in the best way, Perfect!
